turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Is Dr. Frock safe!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes, he's fine.  Greg... take care of yourself!

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Got to finish this thesis sometime.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How about lunch?

turns.speaker: KAWAKITA
turns.text: Not today.  Besides, I think the director of the museum is expecting you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI. Forgive me.  I guess I was snooping. What is this?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: An invention of mine.  It's a computer program designed to describe the characteristics of a given species from a reading of its DNA.  I call it the Genetic Sequence Extrapolator.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: How does it work?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: With a DNA analysis from a fossil you can use this program to tell the species and sex of the animal, whether it was nocturnal, what it ate, how it hunted, how big it was...  You aren't here for a lesson in DNA.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: No.  I came to talk about Dr. John Whittlesley.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Somehow, when all this happened... I knew it would come back to John.  Is he really dead?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Maybe not.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: If he were alive he'd have contacted me.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You have time to talk?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Dr. Whittlesley was last seen in Belem, Venezuela a week after the rest of his expedition disappeared. A taxi driver drove him to the harbor where he boarded a cargo boat.  That boat washed up in my district.  Everyone on board was killed.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And John?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Disappeared.  His body wasn't among the victims.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: The people killed were mauled and their brains were eaten.  Just like Beauregard.  One part of the brain was extracted with surgical precision.  The hypothalamus and thalamus to be exact.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: John couldn't have anything to do with a horrible thing like that.  He was a fine man despite his problems --

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You loved him.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes.  Once.  We met at Columbia.  John held the Cadwalader Chair in Statistical Paleontology when I was a grad student there.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You were going to be married.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How did you know that?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I ran an internet search on Dr. Whittlesley.  Got a list of his scholarly articles and the engagement announcement in the Times.  I also found a record of your restraining order.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That was two years ago.  John was still in love with me.  He wouldn't leave me alone.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You were afraid of him, weren't you?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: He was afraid of himself.  He tried suicide once.  He was ill.  Manic depressive.  He had wild emotional highs and lows.  Not a happy affliction for a scientist.  He'd been revered in our community.  By the end he was a joke.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Tell me about the last expedition. What was he looking for?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A legendary monster called Mbwun.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: A monster?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes.  He developed his own theory that he called the Calisto Effect. It held that evolution wasn't always gradual or driven by natural selection.  The environment would sometimes cause sudden and grotesque changes which could result in a "monster species".  It made no sense. But he felt he had evidence that Mbwun was such a monster, living in isolation on the tepui for thousands of years.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: No one knows.  The Kothoga who live on the tepui are cannibals.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: No.  I'm all right.  I won't let this affect me anymore.  John wouldn't get help.  His ego endangered the lives of others.  His theory came first.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: What if Whittlesley arrived on the tepui and no monster was there?  Was he desperate enough to create one?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Something came up in autopsy tonight.  Imbedded in Beauregard's body we found a claw.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: My God.  Then it was an animal.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I don't think so.  I think we were meant to think it was Mbwun.  Did Whittlesley's monster have claws?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't know.  He sent back a statue that's supposed to be an exact representation.  But I've never seen it.  It's in the exhibit.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Would you mind showing it to me?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Where would we find it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm not sure.  We should split up. You take that hall and I'll take this one.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: All right.  I'm as macho as you are. Perhaps.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I heard you calling and I ran after you, but you kept disappearing and I couldn't keep up.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You were behind me?  Running after me?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's okay, I'm all right.  I remember now... It was an animal.  Something large!  I could smell it.  It was hunting me.  I saw two green eyes in the dark.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Where did you see it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Behind me.  Over there.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That's not what I saw.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: All right.  If you're positive.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Dr. Green...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I didn't imagine it.  I know what I saw.  Are you sure there are enough men in there?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: They're all heavily armed.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: All right.  This is hard for me.  I'm a scientist.  I like order and logic. Sometimes too much.  There's got to be an explanation.  There can't be an animal in there.  But I saw something.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: What was it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't know.  Mr. Pendergast.  Do me a favor.  Get me a DNA readout on that claw.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Genetic damage?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: When DNA is defective, it often uncontrollably replicates long repeating sequences of the same base pair.  Viruses can damage DNA.  So can radiation, certain chemicals.  Even cancer.  Let's let the G.S.E. sort it out.  I have to get started.  This will take several hours.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: We need someone to take us to the secure storage area.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Pendergast?  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: No.  I think I'm hallucinating.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You're not.  Where is it?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Gone.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Wounded?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: No.  A chromium alloy tipped .45 caliber bullet bounced off that thing's skull like a spit ball.  I think it was bothered by my light.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That would fit.  It's nocturnal. Quick.  Come inside.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I don't know how to deal with this. It's hellish.  Like nothing I ever saw.  I'm not trained to deal with a monster, a supernatural creature like that.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's not supernatural.  Mbwun is an animal.  Part lizard, part human, a genetic freak of some kind, like the half-goat, half-sheep they found last year in the jungles of Vietnam.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: But this isn't the jungle!  This is New York.  How did it get here?  A thing like that crossed two continents.  It makes no sense!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: But what can we do?  Our guns are useless --

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: We have the fibers.  Don't you see? The creature is hungry.  It wants the hormones in these plants.  It would take hundreds of human brains to supply what's in these fibers.  We're just a poor substitute.  To make it stop hunting, we have to give it what it wants.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You'd slow us down and put Margo in danger.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Unlock one of the other storage rooms.  We're going upstairs.  We'll leave a trail back to 1012 and try to trap the monster in here.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: That was D'Agosta.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The planetarium!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Vince!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Is there another way around?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: No.  The planetarium is in the next cell.  This is one of the fire doors...

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Hide quickly!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What is it doing?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: It's scared of me.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Its eyesight is worse than I thought.  It couldn't see us.  And it couldn't smell us through the glass.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: It didn't want the fibers.  What does that mean?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I think... it means it's full.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Then it won't go after the others?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: No.  It's still hunting, but not for the hormones.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I think... for the pleasure of the kill.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: We have to try and draw it off!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The answer's right in front of us.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That's a ptarmigan, feigning a broken wing.  The bird pretends to be injured to draw the fox away from its nest!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: It's deceptively simple.  Like a Bruckner Symphony or a Matisse.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Help someone!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Oh God!  Help!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You smell that?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: It's coming.  Run.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: We're not going to make the storage room!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Listen to me, Pendergast.  Mbwun's DNA is part homo sapien.  In primates, the eye is a direct path to the brain!  If you get a clean shot, there's only one place you can kill it.  Shoot it in the eye!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: No!  Don't kill him!  Pendergast, you were right.  It's John!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That thing is John Whittlesley.  I should have seen it before!  The fibers are infected with a virus. You eat them, and the virus alters your DNA!  He became addicted to them in South America, followed the plants back to the states.  He probably entered the country as a man.  It would have taken several months for the change to take place. That's how he got from the boat to the museum!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You have to!  Listen!  All viruses pass on their own DNA.  Instruct the cells of the host to make more viruses!  This one was different.  It inserted a whole array of genes into John.  Reptile genes, sixty five million years old.  Those genes remade him!  It's not his fault!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: Whatever that thing is, we have to kill it!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Just like John.  He won't listen.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I have to shoot.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Do it, quickly.  Please.  Aim for the eye.

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: He has to look here or I won't get a clear shot.  Call him, Margo.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I can't!

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: You have to.  Do it now!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm so glad to see you.  What's the occasion?

turns.speaker: PENDERGAST
turns.text: I'm in town on a case.  Dropped by to see Vince and we thought we'd see the new display.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: I'm sorry to keep you.  How can I help?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I want to book a flight to Fiji.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Where exactly?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Fiji.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Where in Fiji? What island?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I'm sorry, er...the biggest one.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Viti Levu.  For how many?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: One.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: When do you want to leave, remembering, of course, you do lose a day on the way there?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Today.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I don't have anything for at least a month.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: A month.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: It's the busy season.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: You are a travel agent, aren't you?  "Doris"?  Your job is to help people travel.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: I do have a fabulous rate on a cruise ship departing for Fiji tomorrow.  But you wouldn't want to do that.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Why wouldn't I?

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: I thought you were in a hurry.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: You want to book the flight?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: It doesn't matter.  I'll make other arrangements.

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: Close up?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: No, hold back...

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Why is he in the basement?

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: He moved down there after Meryl packed up and left.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Why wasn't I told?  Any unpredictable behavior has to be reported.  Is that the best shot we can get?

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: What's to see?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: What's on the ClockCam?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: What happened down there?

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: He was tidying up his garbage.  I was going to call you.  But half-way through, he gave up and fell asleep.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Give me a shot from Truman's ring.

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: He gave it back to his father.

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: We've declared a curfew.  Everyone else is at first positions.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: All prop cars accounted for?

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: He has to be on foot.  He has the world's most recognizable face.  He can't disappear.

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: I'm sure we'll get him on this next sweep.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: What have we missed?

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: It's just a matter of time.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: We're not watching the sea.

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: Why would we--

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Sweep the harbor.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Cue music...

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: What music?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Storm music...Wagner...

turns.speaker: SIMEON
turns.text: He doesn't care.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Do it!

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Welcome.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: The catalyst for the recent dramatic events was of course Truman's father, Kirk, and his infiltration onto the show. Before we discuss that, it's worth reminding viewers that this isn't the first time someone from the outside world has tried to reach Truman.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: We have had our close calls in the past.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Of course, there hasn't been anything to compare with this - the first time an intruder has been a former cast member--

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: --a dead one at that.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: --and certainly the first time that an intruder has been rewarded with a starring role.  I really must congratulate you on writing Kirk back in.  A master stroke.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Since Kirk started this whole crisis in Truman's life, I came to the conclusion that he was the only one who could end it.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: I understand he's hardly had a life of his own since he left the show.  How did you convince him--was it the opportunity to be close to Truman again?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: That and a fat, new contract.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: How do you intend to explain his twenty- two year absence?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Amnesia.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Let's talk ratings.  "Truman" has always enjoyed top ten status but the huge surge over the last few days--how do you hope to sustain that audience now that Truman appears to have reconciled himself?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: As you know ratings have never been our primary goal.  I imagine we'll lose those voyeurs only interested in witnessing Truman's latest torment.  However, I'm certain that our core audience will remain loyal.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: But recent events have been so dramatic, it does raise the perennial question. What keeps us watching this one man twenty-four hours a day - eating, sleeping, working, sitting for hours in contemplation?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: It has to be the reality.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: We've become tired of watching actors give us phony emotions, bored with pyrotechnics and special effects.  While the world he inhabits is counterfeit, there's nothing fake about Truman himself.  No scripts, no cue cards.  It's not always Shakespeare but it's genuine.  That's how he can support an entire channel.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: A window onto the human condition?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: I prefer to think of it as a mirror.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Not only does he give us a glimpse of the truth, he gives us a glimpse of ourselves.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: But how do you account for the popularity of those eight hours a day when Truman sleeps?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: We find many viewers leave him on all night for comfort.  Haven't you ever watched your child or your lover sleep?

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Let's go to some of those viewers' calls.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Are we talking Emmies?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Certainly a nomination.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Of course, Truman has always been very much in on casting.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: As with our own lives, the only people he can't cast are his family.  Otherwise he has final approval, able to elevate an extra into a lead role as was the case with his only real friend, Marlon, or alternatively relegate a star to a bit player.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Istanbul, Turkey, you're on with master videographer, Christof.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: We should remind viewers that Truman, especially as a child, presented a challenge for the production.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Let me demonstrate some examples.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: He was curious from birth - premature by two weeks, as if he couldn't wait to get started.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Of course, his eagerness to leave his mother's womb also meant he was the one selected.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: In competition with five other unwanted pregnancies - the casting of a show determined by an air date - he was the one who arrived on cue.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Who knew that a show originally meant to last one year - "Bringing Up Baby" - would turn into a "cradle to grave" concept.  He is in fact the first child in the world to be legally adopted by a corporation.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: That's correct.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: And the show now generates a yearly income equivalent to the gross national product of a small country.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: People forget it takes the population of an entire country to keep the show running.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: No, of course not.  And since the show runs 24 hours a day with no commercial breaks the staggering profits are all generated from product placement.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Yes, everything you see on the show is for sale - from the actors' wardrobe, food products, to the very homes they live in--

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: All products carefully chosen and tested by you for quality and aesthetic value.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: There's nothing on the show I don't use myself.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: And it's all available in the "Truman" Show" catalogue.  Operators are standing by.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Why do you feel that Truman's never come close to discovering the true nature of his world?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: We accept the reality of the world with which we're presented.  As the show expanded, naturally we were forced to manufacture ways to keep Truman in Seahaven - demonstrating that every venture is accompanied by a risk.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: You've never actually met Truman, yourself.  Never thought about doing a cameo--playing a veterinarian, or a priest, something like that?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: I've been tempted.  But I think it's important to retain objectivity.  I wouldn't want to get emotionally caught up.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: The Hague for Christof...The Hague?...lost them.  Hollywood, California, you're on "Tru Talk."

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: We've learnt about life as Truman has and, despite the complaints of a minority, it's been an overwhelmingly positive experience, for Truman and for the viewing public.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Let's take another call.  London, England, you're on "Tru Talk."

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: I'm the creator.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: The creator of what?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: A show - that gives hope and joy and inspiration to millions.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: A show. Then who am I?

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: You're the star.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Nothing was real.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: You were real. That's what made you you so good to watch.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I have a map.

turns.speaker: CHRISTOF
turns.text: Truman, I've watched you your whole life. I saw you take your first step, your first word, your first kiss.  I know you better than you know yourself.  You're not going to walk out that door--

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: --You never had a camera in my head.

turns.speaker: DAUGHTER
turns.text: What's he doing?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: They removed all physical trace of her but they couldn't erase the memory.

turns.speaker: DAUGHTER
turns.text: The memory of who?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Shhh!

turns.speaker: DAUGHTER
turns.text: But why didn't he just follow her to Fiji?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Because his mother got sick - very sick.  He couldn't leave her.  He's a kind boy, maybe too kind.

turns.speaker: DAUGHTER
turns.text: I can't believe he married Meryl on the rebound.

turns.speaker: GUARD 1
turns.text: How can they have a child?

turns.speaker: GUARD 2
turns.text: It's not gonna be his, you idiot.

turns.speaker: GUARD 1
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GUARD 2
turns.text: You think she'd go through with it?

turns.speaker: GUARD 1
turns.text: Sure she would.

turns.speaker: GUARD 2
turns.text: Guess I always thought they'd adopt.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: You take Japanese.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Lauren, right?

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: That's right.  Lauren.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I'm Truman, Truman Burbank--

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: --I'm not allowed to talk to you.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: It's okay.  I probably wouldn't talk to me either.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: I'm sorry.  It's not up to me.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: You have a boyfriend?  Of course you do.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: No...I, er.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: No?  Really?  Good, I mean, I thought possibly a pizza.  How about Friday?

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Saturday?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Actually, I'm free Sunday.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: Now.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Right now?  We've got finals tomorrow.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: If we don't go now, it won't happen.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: Well, what do you want to do?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I think I've studied enough.

turns.speaker: LAUREN
turns.text: It's beautiful!  What are you waiting for?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I...I can't.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I'm thinking of getting out, Marlon.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Yeah?  Outta what?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Outta my job, outta Seahaven, off this island...out!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: See here, this is us.  All the way round here, Fiji.  You can't get any further away before you start coming back.  Y'know, there are still islands in Fiji where no human has ever set foot.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: So when are you leaving?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: It's not that simple.  Takes money, planning.  You can't just up and go.  Oh, I'm going to do it, don't worry about that.  I've just got to move slow.  Pick my moment.  Bonus time's just around the corner.  Soon as I finish the...

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Nursery?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Spare room - I can start thinking about selling up...and I'll be gone. Up and away on that big steel bird. I'm going, don't you worry about that.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Truman, you know, I did think about moving away one time.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Yeah, what happened?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: I figured, what's the point?  I knew I'd just be taking my problems with me.  Once the kids came along, it made me look at Seahaven with new eyes.  I realized, what the hell could be better than this?  I'm telling you.  What you really need is someone to carry on the "Burbank" name.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Trust me.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: You really think it could've dropped off an airliner?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Sure.  It's halogen.  Shame it didn't hit you - you could've sued.  You coming for a drink?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I can't tonight.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Marlon--

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: --Truman, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I've got to talk to you.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Sorry, I'm way behind.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I'm onto something, Marlon - something big.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Are you okay?  You look like shit.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I think I'm mixed up in something.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Mixed up? Mixed up in what?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: There's no point in trying to explain it, but a lot of strange things have been happening - elevators that don't go anywhere, people talking about me on the radio, you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: No.  Truman, if this is another one of your fantasies...

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I think it's got something to do with my dad.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Your Dad?!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I think he's alive.  I'll tell you about it later.  I'm definitely being followed.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: It's hard to tell.  They look just like regular people.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: How about them?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Could be.  Beard looks phony.  It's when I'm unpredictable.  They can't stand that.  That's why we've got to get out of here.  Can you come with me?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: I told you I can't.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I've got to show you something.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: What're we doing here, Truman?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: This is where it started.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: What exactly?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Things.  Things that doesn't fit.  Maybe I'm being set up for something. You ever feel like that, Marlon?  Like your whole life has been building to something?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: When you were hauling chickens for Kaiser Poultry, what was the furthest you ever went off the island?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: I went all over but I never found a place like this.  Look at that sunset, Truman.  It's perfect.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: That's the "Big Guy".  Quite a paintbrush he's got.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Just between you and me, Marlon, I'm going away for a while.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Stay where you are!

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Truman?  It's me, Marlon.  I need to talk to you.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I don't know what to think, Marlon. Maybe I'm going out of my mind, but I get the feeling that the world revolves around me somehow.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: It's a lot of world for one man.  You sure that's not wishful thinking, you wishing you'd made something more of yourself? Christ, Truman, who hasn't sat on the John and had an imaginary interview on "Seahaven Tonight"?  Who hasn't wanted to be somebody?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: This is different.  Everybody seems to be in on it.

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: And the last thing I'd ever do is lie to you. Think about it, Truman, if everybody's in on it, I'd have to be in on it too. I'm not in on it, because there is no it.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: So what are you saying, Marlon, the whole thing has been in my head--?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: Not the whole thing, Truman.  You were right about one thing.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MARLON
turns.text: The thing that started all of this.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: ...personally I think the unconquered south face is the only one worth scaling...of course it's a 20,000 foot sheer wall of ice but then when did that ever stop me before?...Naturally, I intend to make the ascent without the benefit of oxygen but also without crampons or even an ice pick...risks?... ...sure I'm aware of the risks--why else do you think I would spend seven years as an adjuster in a life insurance company...?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Truman, you're gonna be late!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: It's a surprise.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Well, what do you think?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: They're...  perfect.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Hi, honey.  Look at this.  It's a "Chef's-Mate."  Dicer, slicer and peeler in one.  Never needs sharpening. Dishwasher safe.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Gee, that's great.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: How did it go today?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: A man tripped and fell on a chainsaw.  We got three of his fingers back on.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I was hoping we could have a special evening.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I won't be late.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Did something happen today?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Where have you been?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I've been thinking--

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Oh, God.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: --I figure we could scrape together eight thousand.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Every time you and Marlon--

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: --We could bum around the world for a year on that.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: And then what, Truman?  We'd be back to where we were five years ago.  You're talking like a teenager.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Maybe I feel like a teenager.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: We're mortgaged to the eyeballs, Truman. There's the car payments.  Are we just going to walk away from our financial obligations?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: It'd be an adventure.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I thought we were going to try for a baby.  Isn't that enough of an adventure?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: That can wait.  I want to get away.  See some of the world.  Explore.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: This'll pass.  Everybody thinks like this now and then.  Come to bed.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I think I'm going to stay up for a while.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: What're you doing down here?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Fixing the mower.  I saw my father today.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Your mother called.  You shouldn't upset her like that.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: What did you want?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I made macaroni.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Come on, Truman.  Haven't you studied enough?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I still want to look over a couple of things.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I'll take you home, Angela.  Why don't you leave those with us for a while?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Good night, Mother.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: See you in a minute, sweetheart.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I have to talk with you.  But not here.  Let's go for a walk.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I'm sorry, I'm late.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: What's the hurry?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Surgery.  The elevator disaster downtown on the news last night.  Cable snapped, a car dropped ten floors.  Non-union contractors.  Monsters.  We're starting with an amputation.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Arrah!

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Oh, my God!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: What do I do?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I don't know--

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: --you're a nurse, aren't you?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Put some butter on it--or ice?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: I invited Marlon and Rita for a barbeque Sunday.  I thought I'd make my potato salad.  Remind me--

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I won't be here Sunday.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: --we need more charcoal.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Are you listening to a word I'm saying?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: You're upset because you want to go to Fiji.  Is that it?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Let's go now.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Where shall we go?  Where shall we go? Spontaneity is what it's all about. Forget Fiji.  We can't very well drive to Fiji, can we?  What about Atlantic City?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: You hate gambling.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: That's right.  I do, don't I?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: So why do you want to go?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Because I never have.  That's why you go places, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Truman, I think I'm going to throw up.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Blocked at every turn.  Beautifully synchronized, don't you agree?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: You blaming me for the traffic?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Should I?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Truman, that was our house!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I've changed my mind again.  What's New Orleans like this time of year?  Mardi Gras.  Or let's just see where the road takes us.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Let me out, Truman.  You're not right in the head.  You want to destroy yourself, you do it on your own!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I think I'd like a little company.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: It's hard to go places, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: There's been an accident, Truman.

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: Uhuh.  There's no accident.  It's just more stalling.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Truman, I took the "hypocrite" oath!

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I bet you did.

turns.speaker: MERYL
turns.text: Truman, what about that sign?

turns.speaker: TRUMAN
turns.text: I'm sure they're just exaggerating.
